learning_outcomes.description: Understand the ways in which performance texts are adapted to engage intended or specific audiences.
Identify generic features of texts in performance.
Appreciate the effects that specific spaces can have on performance adaptations.
Understand the potential that the performing body has to influence the audience's interpretation of a text.
Comprehend the importance of elements of performance on audience reception of theatre through a group performance or backstage secondment in practice.
Have an awareness of the historical context of a range of plays.

assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
This task assesses your engagement with the course across the Semester. Across the first two-thirds of semester, your engagement with the course content and tutorial activities is worth 2.5% per week. You will be assessed on the basis of five components: preparation for class (including having read the set text/s and absorption of the lecture content); engagement with the learning activities in class; development of the ideas of others; and respectful peer collaboration and your engagement with the play text and the idea being discussed.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This is an in-person assessment completed during normal tutorial hours.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will attend a live performance, and will write a performance review reflecting on how TWO elements of performance (genre, structure, time, space, body, language) manifest in, and influence your experience of the performance. The precise details of the live performance to be attended will be provided to students as soon as practically possible. Please note students are responsible for buying their own tickets, and attending the production independently of the course timetable.

A fully detailed assignment brief will be made available via Blackboard early in the semester.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit this assessment via Turnitin on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This task is designed to allow you to demonstrate your understanding of the elements of performance through practice. You do this through one of three ways: either as an actor, working under the guidance of a DRAM3105 director to realise a performance in a short play; as an actor, devising a short performance in collaboration with a group of your DRAM1010 peers; or via a secondment to the backstage crew, working on the DRAM3105 festival of student work.

Detailed assignment briefs for each path will be provided via Blackboard. 

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment

  • All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)
  • Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.
  • Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of:
  • Moderation of marking;
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment will take place in person, during Vanguard Theatre Festival at the Avalon Theatre in Week 13. Students will be required to be available outside of class time for technical and dress rehearsals, and during the evening on at least two days of the festival. You will also be assessed on your participation in rehearsals.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to upload a 500-word critical reflection on how performance engages with either audiences or festivals, where you reflect on what you learnt about the audience/ or festivals from your experience of participating in a student theatre festival.

The referencing style used for Drama assignments is MLA, 9th edition. 

A detailed assessment brief will be provided on Blackboard early in semester.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit this assessment via Turnitin on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction - Elements of Performance

This lecture will introduce the six key elements of performance covered in the course, as well as familiarise students with the assessment regime and other course requirements.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction - Elements of Performance This lecture will introduce the six key elements of performance covered in the course, as well as familiarise students with the assessment regime and other course requirements.

learning_activities.topic: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Genre - Agamemnon

The first element, genre, will be introduced with reference to the historical division between tragedy and comedy, dating from Ancient Greek theatre.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Genre - Agamemnon The first element, genre, will be introduced with reference to the historical division between tragedy and comedy, dating from Ancient Greek theatre.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Staging Genre

In this tutorial, students will experiment with the text of "Agamemnon" to understand how genre has been staged across time, with specific reference to formal devices from Greek tragedy.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Staging Genre In this tutorial, students will experiment with the text of "Agamemnon" to understand how genre has been staged across time, with specific reference to formal devices from Greek tragedy.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Structure - Love and Information

This lecture will introduce students to the basic elements of structure, with particular reference to the plot/narrative divide (that is, how can similar stories be told in different ways?).


Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Structure - Love and Information This lecture will introduce students to the basic elements of structure, with particular reference to the plot/narrative divide (that is, how can similar stories be told in different ways?).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Building Structure

This tutorial will use selected scenes from "Love & Information" in order to experiment with building structure in performance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Building Structure This tutorial will use selected scenes from "Love & Information" in order to experiment with building structure in performance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Time - Sunshine Super Girl

This lecture will consider the ways in which playwrights use time to create dramatic meaning, and how time can be related to (and enact) structure.

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Time - Sunshine Super Girl This lecture will consider the ways in which playwrights use time to create dramatic meaning, and how time can be related to (and enact) structure.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Marking Time

In this tutorial, we will experiment with different techniques of marking time in performance, with specific reference to the distinction between 'real' time and dramatic time in "Sunshine Super Girl".

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Marking Time In this tutorial, we will experiment with different techniques of marking time in performance, with specific reference to the distinction between 'real' time and dramatic time in "Sunshine Super Girl".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Space - Picnic at Hanging Rock

This lecture considers the real and imagined spaces and places in which performance takes place, using the case study of contemporary Australian plays.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Space - Picnic at Hanging Rock This lecture considers the real and imagined spaces and places in which performance takes place, using the case study of contemporary Australian plays.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Playing in Space

This tutorial will experiment with the many and varied uses of space in performance, and consider in particular how space can be used to complicate the effects of time and structure in "Picnic at Hanging Rock".

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Playing in Space This tutorial will experiment with the many and varied uses of space in performance, and consider in particular how space can be used to complicate the effects of time and structure in "Picnic at Hanging Rock".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Body - Twelfth Night

This lecture will examine the central role of the body in performance, using the case study of the historical progression of actors who have played the character of Malvolio in "Twelfth Night".

Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Body - Twelfth Night This lecture will examine the central role of the body in performance, using the case study of the historical progression of actors who have played the character of Malvolio in "Twelfth Night".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Bending Bodies

This tutorial will examine selected scenes from "Twelfth Night" in order to explore how the body might be deployed meaningfully in performance, and especially how the body relates to space.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Bending Bodies This tutorial will examine selected scenes from "Twelfth Night" in order to explore how the body might be deployed meaningfully in performance, and especially how the body relates to space.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Language - Arturo Ui

Analysing the distinctive style of Brecht's "Arturo Ui", which itself draws on older traditions of verse playwriting, this lecture will how language enacts and constitutes performance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Language - Arturo Ui Analysing the distinctive style of Brecht's "Arturo Ui", which itself draws on older traditions of verse playwriting, this lecture will how language enacts and constitutes performance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Language at Work

This tutorial will examine the ways in which language can create character and help shape genre using scenes from Brecht's "Arturo Ui."

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Language at Work This tutorial will examine the ways in which language can create character and help shape genre using scenes from Brecht's "Arturo Ui."

learning_activities.topic: Week 8: NO LECTURE
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: NO LECTURE

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: AUDITIONS

Tutorials will be be given over to auditions, in which students who wish to be considered for the DRAM3105 collaboration along the Performance pathway audition for directors, using material from "Arturo Ui".

This is an opt-out activity.

Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: AUDITIONS Tutorials will be be given over to auditions, in which students who wish to be considered for the DRAM3105 collaboration along the Performance pathway audition for directors, using material from "Arturo Ui". This is an opt-out activity.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Elements of Performance - Hedda Gabler

This lecture will offer a case study of the elements of performance working together in the live theatre experience.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Elements of Performance - Hedda Gabler This lecture will offer a case study of the elements of performance working together in the live theatre experience.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: The elements at work

This tutorial will explore the relationship between the six elements of performance using "Hedda Gabler" as an example.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: The elements at work This tutorial will explore the relationship between the six elements of performance using "Hedda Gabler" as an example.

learning_activities.topic: Mid-Semester Break: NO LECTURE
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid-Semester Break: NO LECTURE

learning_activities.topic: Mid-Semester Break: NO TUTORIALS
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid-Semester Break: NO TUTORIALS

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Audiencing the Elements

This lecture will introduce core terminology and historical context around theatre audiences.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Audiencing the Elements This lecture will introduce core terminology and historical context around theatre audiences.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Vanguard Rehearsals

The tutorial time will be given over to rehearsal for the upcoming Vanguard Festival, ensuring Performance and Devising pathway students are able to seek feedback from their tutor. Performance and Devising pathway students may be asked to attend a different tutorial in weeks 10-12. Students on the Secondment pathway are not expected to attend tutorials this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Vanguard Rehearsals The tutorial time will be given over to rehearsal for the upcoming Vanguard Festival, ensuring Performance and Devising pathway students are able to seek feedback from their tutor. Performance and Devising pathway students may be asked to attend a different tutorial in weeks 10-12. Students on the Secondment pathway are not expected to attend tutorials this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Festivaling the Elements

In this lecture, we will explore the dramaturgy of festivals in an Australian context, examining the role of the festival in the Australian theatre context.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Festivaling the Elements In this lecture, we will explore the dramaturgy of festivals in an Australian context, examining the role of the festival in the Australian theatre context.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Vanguard Rehearsals

The tutorial time will be given over to rehearsal for the upcoming Vanguard Festival, ensuring Performance and Devising pathway students are able to seek feedback from their tutor. Performance and Devising pathway students may be asked to attend a different tutorial in weeks 10-12. Students on the Secondment pathway are not expected to attend tutorials this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Vanguard Rehearsals The tutorial time will be given over to rehearsal for the upcoming Vanguard Festival, ensuring Performance and Devising pathway students are able to seek feedback from their tutor. Performance and Devising pathway students may be asked to attend a different tutorial in weeks 10-12. Students on the Secondment pathway are not expected to attend tutorials this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Conclusion

This lecture will conclude the substantive course material by arguing that every act of performance is an act of adaptation to a specific time and place, and therefore reliant on the interplay of the elements of performance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12: Conclusion This lecture will conclude the substantive course material by arguing that every act of performance is an act of adaptation to a specific time and place, and therefore reliant on the interplay of the elements of performance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Technical Rehearsals

In preparation for the delivery of the Group Performance Project, technical rehearsals will be held from Saturday 25 October through Tuesday 28 October. These calls will be for the late afternoon and evening. Secondment students will also be required at various times across Thursday 23 to Friday 24 October. A schedule will be provided closer to the date.

Learning outcomes: L01, L05

These calls will be for the late afternoon and evening. Secondment students will also be required at various times across Thursday 23 to Friday 24 October. A schedule will be provided closer to the date.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: UQ Drama - Your Future

Morning tea during the normal lecture slot, held in the usual teaching space. The UQ Drama staff will introduce the advanced Drama program, and map out the options for further Drama study after successful completion of DRAM1010.

The UQ Drama staff will introduce the advanced Drama program, and map out the options for further Drama study after successful completion of DRAM1010.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Performances

The Group Performance Projects will be delivered across three evenings of performance, from Wednesday 29 October through Friday 1 November. You will be required to perform on one evening, and attend as an audience member on at least one other (COVID-restrictions pending). You will also be required for a dress rehearsal on the day of your performance. A schedule will be provided closer to the date.

Learning outcomes: L01, L05, L06
